newsitem.title: FINLAND: Finnish ministry sees no leeway in state finances.
newsitem.headline: Finnish ministry sees no leeway in state finances.

text.p: The Finnish finance ministry on Wednesday warned of an excessive deficit in state finances if taxation was eased without matching spending cuts.
In a statement outlining key economic projections until 2001, the ministry said the state finances would not allow any room to manoeuver in the next few years.

"Tax cuts without compensating measures can easily lead to a too big deficit of the state finances," it said. The ministry gave no figures and did not say what would be excessive. "A simultaneous reduction in state expenditure should be attached to any potential easing (of taxation)," it said.

Earlier decisions by the government to keep state budget spending largely unchanged in nominal terms in the next few years would require austere expenditure policy as debt-servicing spending continued to increase, the ministry said.
It forecast steady economic growth until 2001, projecting an average annual growth rate of 3.5 percent in 1996-2001.
Unemployment would fall, but too slowly compared to the government's target to halve the jobless rate to 8-9 percent by 1999, the ministry said. @
